poem:
**Caesar in the Glass**  

A lithe orange flicker—  
Caesar's tail cuts  
through still water,  
echoes a child's laughter.  
Behind the glass,  
worlds collide,  
the minister's brief prayer,  
and a fish, immortalized.  
In a tank, stories swim—  
memory's gentle wave.  
An ordinary goldfish,  
an extraordinary grace.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The pet I’ll never forget: Caesar the goldfish, who meant as much to me as any dog To anyone else, Caesar would have seemed an ordinary goldfish, swimming in his orange, bug-eyed way around his tank. To me, though, he was immortal, thanks to one of those family stories that mean so much when you’re a child. Dad, a Methodist minister in Bradford, was about to leave for a church meeting when he realised that". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
